New security at Hut
BY CHRIS STUTZ
This year, as students make
their first reluctant passage
through the glass portals of the
Hutzler Reading Room, they will
encounter something new: an
electronic book security system.
Students will walk through a
frame-like structure immediately
inside the entrance which detects
the presence of sensitized
"objects" hidden in the books.
Due to the increasing number of
lost books in recent years, the
System was installed to. protect
the remaining volumes. If this
System is successful, another may
be purchased for use in the
Eisenhower library.
According to studies
C onducted by Shirley Baker,
Hutzler Undergraduate Librarian,
the most frequently used books

at Hutzler are the study aids, that
is, reference books and texts that
.supplement students' assigned
texts. Formerly, these texts were
available on a circulating basis
(except, of course, for
non-circulating reference
materials) but, because of their
value to students, they often
disappeared soon after their
purchase. Thus students who
came to Hutzler seeking a
specific and often crucial text,
such as Lehninger or the CRC
Handbook, could never depend
upon finding it on the shelves. It
is in the interest of serving the
entire student body, therefore,
that this security system has been
instituted.
The most used portion of the
six thousand books in the
collection (about two-thirds)
have been made non-circulating,

The Johns Hopkins University
School Of Medicine has indicated
that it will sacrifice as much as
$700,000 next year in federal
assistance by refusing to change
its admissions policies for foreign
transfer students.
The school will become
ineligible to receive certain
federal grants because of its
refusal to comply with Section
771B, Title VII, of Public Law
94-484. This provision, part of a
Health Manpower bill, calls for a
school seeeking renewed grants to
agree to accept a government-set
quota of U.S. citizens who have
begun their medical studies
abroad.
According to the provision,
the eligibility of these students
would be determined solely by
the Department of Health,
Education, and Welfare. The only
university criteria they would
have to meet would be entrance
requirements, rather than
academic requirements. As
explained by medical school
Assistant Dean for Academic
Affairs Dr. John Yardley, this
would mean that an applicant
would be responsible for having
taken organic chemistry, for
example, but not for having
received an "A" or "B" mark in
that course, or any specified
grade point average.
In an open letter sent to
members of Congress, President
Steven Muller held that the
so that they are always available
for those who need them. The
other two thousand books are
stored at another location and
can be obtained on request. Ms.

faculty and the MSE Reserve
Room staff in order to determine
which books should be kept in

Hopkins and CIA: No big sneeze
On August 18, the Johns
Hopkins University was notified
that it was among the eighty
Institutions involved in the
C I A- fu nded MK-ULTRA
Program. The announcement,
which came two days after the
University of Maryland had
received a similar notice, has
been perhaps the only clear piece
of information in the unravelling
of this rather curious spy tale.
Between November, 1958 and
August, 1962, CIA monies were
used to finance a study of highly
'allergic substances." Just what
those substances wre, and who
Was involved in their production

is unclear, and because of the
sketchy nature of the facts of the
case, it is doubtful that they ever
will be. Still, according to the
University's general counsel,
Estelle A. Fishbein, there was no
indication that the research
involved human subjects.
Perhaps the principal reason
for the enigma is that the bulk of
the MK-ULTRA records now
extant are mostly financial
rec ords, and add only
fragmentary information on the
nature of each of the projects.
Oddly enough, until these
records had been found, most of
the information on MK ULTRA

was believed to have Peen
destroyed in 1973, according to a
statement by the agency's general
counsel, Anthony A. Lapham.
Most of the documents
examined by Mrs. Fishbein were
vouchers and expense forms,
averaging about four thousand
dollars a year. Fishbein noted
that there was an "inordinate"
amount of paperwork concerning
an $18.26 discrepancy.
As for the nature of the
research itself, less is clear. One
of the documents inspected
stated that the Hopkins work was
"To purify and characterized

provision "violates the rights of
the University under the First
and Fifth Amendments of the
Constitution of the United
States."
Muller further cited a Supreme
Court decision in which Justice
Felix Frankfurter declared that
one of the four essential
freedoms of a university is "the
right to determine for itself on
academic grounds ... who may be
admitted to study."
In addition to its philosophical
objections, the school also claims
that it cannot increase its
enrollment without lowering the
quality of instruction, and that
foreign medical students are
provided opportunities to enter
the school under its regular
admissions procedures.
President Muller's letter
continues, "The Johns Hopkins
University, after careful
deliberation, and on the basis of
full endorsement in particular by
medical faculty, takes the
position that preservation of
Constitutional rights and
academic integrity leaves no
alternative to non-acceptance."
The six year old program in
question involves capitation
grants, or grants based on the
number of students enrolled.
According to Yardley, the figure
is usually about one thousand
dollars per student, with amounts
up to fourteen hundred being
considered for I 972,Depending

on the Congressional
appropriation, then, the amount
at stake could range from four
hundred thousand to seven
hundred thousand dollars.
University officials hope that
Congress will repeal or amend the
Health Manpower act. Yardley
noted that the provision in
question was added at the last
moment by a Senate-House
conference committee, and that
it was overlooked in debate on
the measure. The University
hopes that bringing the matter to
the attention of Congress may
induce them to act upon it.
An amendment to the
provision has already been
introduced into Congress. This
measure would limit the number
of HEW selected transfer
students to five percent of the
class, or ten students, whichever
is greater. In Hopkins' case, ten
such students would have to be
accepted each year. Yardley
stated that such a figure is still
too high to be acceptable.
In the event that Hopkins loses
its capitation grant funds, Muller
emphasized that the budget at
the medical school will be
reduced. "The resulting financial
burden will not be placed on the
medical students of the
university," the letter states.
• Tuition will be increased at the
medical school next year,
however, due to other factors.

Symposium opens Oct. 6th
"Television and Society: the World in 21" (Diagonally)"
this year's topic for the Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium, will open its
lecture series with Canadian media critic Marshall McLuhan, on October
6 in Shriver Hall.
The Symposium,which is in its eleventh year, began in 1967 as a
tribute to then president Milton Eisenhower. Commenting on the
topical nature of the lectures, Symposium Co-chairman Steve Simms
commented, "In the spirit he helped to encourage, the symposium
explores issues of contemporary impact."
Among previous topics were such issues as "The Nature of
Creativity," "The United States and the Soviet Union: The Dilemma of
Power," and "Aspects of Human Sexuality." Generally, the series draws
wide attention in the media, and several lectures from the Nature of
Creativity were taped for broadcast by PBS. An integral part of
Baltimore's intellectual life, the Symposium's lectures often attract as
many community residents as students.
Unfortunately, not all of the topics succeed, and last years' series,"A
Question of Freedom," was less than successful. Plagued by poor
attendance and little-known speakers, it was felt by some that the
M.S.E. Symposium may have been losing its vigor. This year's

J.D.Considine

nEW1 LECCER
Legislative Morality
Throughout the history of our country, there have been
many discriminatory laws, laws which were not so much
used to marshall order as to stratify class boundaries.
Prohibition, for example, was violated as much by the
upper classes as by the lower, yet was primarily used as a
means of harassment for many lower-class immigrant
groups, especially Irish and Italian Catholics. Similarly, the
marijuana laws have been seen by some (e.g., Garry Wills) as
a means of persecuting the lower class urban dweller, while
the upper class suburbanites are rarely bothered.
Most recently, President Carter engaged in an action
which discriminates not only against class but against sex.
By restricting the use of Federal Health funding to disclude
abortions. Carter has sought to enforce a moral decision '
against a legalistic problem, and in ding so, has attempted'
to decide the morality of a question for others.
In a nutshell, our position is this: If Medical aid is the
right of every individual (and, indeed, this seems to be the
Government's position as well; viz. Medicare, HEW, etc.),
then anymedical operation which is legal in the United
States should be available to all citizens. So long as the
government condones abortion with legality, it is clarly
discriminatory to deny it to those unable to afford it.
The issue here is not whether abortion is moral. The
Right to Life movement should direct their energies to the
repeal of the abortion laws, not the repeal of Federal
funding. President Carter should realize that morality
cannot be legislated, either through direct or indirect
means.

This age of science, like all ages, is a period of
faith in the non-observable, and an age considerably
less practical in all of the important respects than
the age of the religious world view. In that age,
inquisitions and religious wars were, in the first
place, political perversions of an existential
standpoint created by a man who frustrated the
hopes of his contemporaries by insisting that His.
kingdom was not of this world; and, in any event,
modernity can make no claims to comparative
innocence. Our age of rationalism, of "scientific"
ideology, is curiously simultaneous with terrorism,
totalitarianism, and destructive revolution on an
unprecedented scale. Science has so completely
failed to substantiate anyone's humanistic optimism
that its apotheosis is now virtually unheard of. This
development has to do not only with the fact that
science is the matrix of destructive capacity as well
as constructive capacity, but with the fact that
"scientific" analysis brooks no distinctively religious
problems as such in human subjectivity. Rather, it
attempts to analyze these "prima facie" religious
problems into something else, reducing them, in
not
effect, to something that they are
radical empiricism;
experienced as. This is not
it is, rather the ideologizing of man,and it does not
work.
It is the death of man. The modern secular
psychological project, beginning most dramatically
with psychoanalysis in the late nineteenth century,
rooted itself in the rejection of the inexplicable face
of experience in a search for its mechanistic guts.
This was a rejection of the radically experiential
method of defining man for ideological ways of
doing so. The point is that man experiences
freedom, guilt, responsibility, transcendence, and,
traditionally in the West, these were viewed not as
illusions, but rather as the foundational realities of
Man. With the advent of modern scientific analysis
we adopted the assumption that we are simply
fooled into believing these things about ourselves;
the methodological assumption of a hopefully
comprehensive science was that everything had a
cause. Thus we ended up explaining ourselves in
terms of an ideological determinism which we could
not observe and rejecting the freedom, guilt,
responsibility, and transcendence which we could
observe.
Now I certainly think that there is something
definitely specious about this, especially insofar as
we are the ones who come up with the ideology. It
is not that I reject the causal foundations of natural
science, but rather that I reject this foundation as a
comprehensive view of things. It seems odd to apply
it to a consciousness which objectifies the causal
nexus and seems always in a position to break it
once it is known. Sartre, of course, would agree.
Man, from a radically experiential standpoint, is
freedom.
But it is not this rather abstruse philosophical
insight which has broken down psychoanalysis in
less than one hundred years; rather, I am inclined to
believe it is the latter's comparative therapeutic
failure. Today the psychiatrist often deals in
"reality therapy," or "logo-therapy," in which the
face of subjective experience is accepted and the
patient is expected to own up to freedom,
responsibility, and the necessity of decisions leading
to meaning:We live in an era in which a Carl Becker
understands all human behavior as an existential
strategy for escaping death, death as subjective
nothingness, meaninglessness, valuelessness, and
lovelessness. All of which goes to say that we are
turning back to ourselves instead of paying homage
to "scientific" ideology.
But this revolution 114s.only just begun and the
average modern man has not even begun to digest its

Two days ago, as a part of Full Employment Week, the
Interdenominational Minesterial Alliance and the
AFL-CIO staged rallies at City Hall and Center Plaza in an
attempt to call public attention to the current high rate of
unemployment, particularly among blacks. More than
Twenty Baltimore ministers, among them Chaplain
Chester Wickwire, presented a staement which accused
our national leaders of "committing themselves to the
proposition of maintaining high rates of unemployment to
offset the rising price levels attendant to inflation." Such
a policy, of course, shows a crass disregard for the lives of
those unemployed. Particularly hard hit is the Black
community, where the unemployment rate is around 14%.
The percentage of unemployed black adolescents averages
35% and is as high as 70% . In fact, Baltimore ranks
second to Detroit in its rate of unemployment among
black teenagers. The IMA is asking that ;ndividuals write
letters to President Carter and to Representative Parren
Mitchell expressing their concern. Among other things,
they hope that the office of Revenue Sharing will
investigate the use of federal funds in our city and state to
evaluate their availability and use for the needy.
Dr. Wickwire stressed that "we shouldn't be dealing with
economic problems in terms of inflation, but dealing with
them in terms of people." He went on to criticize the lack
of social concern at Hopkins. "How far removed we are
on campus from what's going on down in the city. We're
so isolated from what's going on on the other side of
North Avenue." This coming Sunday, ministers
throughout the city will ask their congregations to write
the President. On campus, Dr. Wickwire hopes that within
the next few days individuals will write letters to Carter
and then drop them off at the office of the Chaplain,
where, sometime early next week, the hopefully large

that he seems to presently promote is hopelessly
Y kJ

non-religious and therefore uninteresting to religious
people as such. The aesthetic surface of a chaplain's
program which is constituted out of religion
courses, ostensibly stuffy seminars about
"individual and societal growth" or "issues in health
care delivery," and volunteer work which could as
well be provided by an Office of Mundane
recherche "relevance." But it is also the reduction
of religion to good anthropology, good ethics, good
politics, and good humanism; and as good as it all is,
it is merely paltry when placed beside Christ's
radical denial of subjective death - this being the
most sublime religious issue in life.
There is no morally authentic humanism in a man
(there is no strength for it) until he has solved the
irreducibly and distinctively religious problem of
life as a personal abyss in which there is the failure
to instantiate value, radical contingency, a dearth of
hope and love, and an abiding despair that he can
only run from. The Chaplain's public program
seems, in the face of this, religiously irrelevant another manifestation of the impoverished modern
emphasis: the relation of ideology to man and man
to man rather than, firstly, the relation of man to
his own subjectivity and consequently to God. It
excludes the religiously fundamental search for a
healthy subjective authenticity. Thus the Chaplain
seems to offer us one more moment in the silence of
God, unless a course on "individual growth" is more
than ideological.
Hegel pointed out that the dialectical product of
God's death is not the promotion of man, but,
rather, the deification of Death itself. But the
scientific age has only "killed" God as a necessary
aspect of limited scientific explanations as such and
cannot, even in principle, "kill" him as a moral
n.ecesity,. not an ultimate explanation. Still, even if
the "death of God" cannot be produced
scientifically and is actually identical with ignorance
of God,the practical effect is not that man becomes
God but, once again, that Death becomes God. The
universe not only remains ultimately inexplicable to
man, but his history becomes a reign of terror. One
hundred years ago Zarathustra came out of the hills
to announce the death of God (albeit, too early);
Orwell and Huxley, in their more recent
pronouncement were much more modest: they
merely descried the death of Man (albeit, too late).
The seemingly manufactured "relevance" of
contemporary "religion" is no resurrection,for it
does not return us to the face of human subjectivity
(nor consequently to the face of God.)
Still, this exact moment of the age remains
uncertain, not clearly a decision to remain with
Death, palling of its own tawdriness. It has squeezed
the magnitude out of everything, including sex,
marriage, and childbearing. In doing so it waters an
already rooted existential rebellion in human nature
which cannot long bear the total absence of the
goodness accruing frOm the fulfillment of moral
duty. The contemporary man's and woman's
totalitarian and loveless behavior toward their own
unborn children is perhaps the most repulsive and
extreme selfishness teleologically implied by the
death of all moral authority - the death of God. The
ugliness, the hollowness, the simple moral
bankruptcy of the West is now unendurable. What
we shall probably have to protect ourselves against
in the next tens to twenty years is the fascist
potential in the inevitable human reaction to it. We
will have to insure that the form this reaction takes
is not politically or religiously authoritarian, but a
matter of religious grace. In this sense, Christ is the
model for authority. Nevertheless, this is not a
model of innocuous piety, for Christ the tiger (as
Eliot put it) subjectively radicalizes men and women
in the face of Death.
--Thomas A. Dahlberz

New faces

BY ROBERT RIGGS
The 1977-78 academic year
gets under way with a variety of
faces in new places. New in
administrative positions are Dr.
Richard Zdanis, Vice president
for Administrative Services, Dr.
Michael Hooker, Assistant to the
Dean of Undergraduate and
Graduate Studies, Mrs. Umran
Uras, Housing Director, and Dr.
Susan Cole,executive assistant to
the president of the University.
Hooker
Dr. Michael
Hooker will continue to teach
courses in the Philosophy
Department while assuming the
newly created position of
Assistant Dean for
Undergraduate and Graduate
Studies. "I expect that I will have
primary responsibility," he
commented, "for dealing with
faculty, students, and parents
regarding such issues as academic
standing and integrity."
"I am freeing up a significant
portion (Dean Suskind's) time,"
he continued, "and one of the
effects will be that the Dean's
office will be able to devote more
time to the search for funding
research and academic
programs."
After graduating summa cum
laude from the University of
North Carolina in 1969, Hooker
obtained his Ph.D. from the
University of Massachusetts at
Amherst in 1973. He then spent
two years as an assistant
professor of philosophy at
Harvard before coming to
Hopkins.
Mrs. Umran Uras is the new
Housing Director for the
University. She became acting
director in April, when she
replaced Larry Frelow. She was
appointed permanently effective
July 1.
Prior to her promotion, she
held the position
of
administrative assistant in the
Housing Office for three years.
She feels that this experience/will
help her as Housing Director.
Currently, she is continuing to
function in the administrative
role, but she stated that she
expects to name a new assistant
within a week.
In addition, Uras is working
towards her master's degree in
Business ,Administration from
Hopkins this semester. She
already has a B.A. in
management from Robert
College in Istanbul, Turkey.
Cole
Dr. Susan Cole was named by
President Muller to replace Mrs.
Elaine Born as executive assistant
to the president of the
University. Mrs. Born stepped
down in order to spend more
time with her family.
Commenting on Cole's
appointment, Muller said: "I am
pleased that Susan Cole has
accepted my invitation to serve
as executive assistant to the
president. Her prior experience at
the National Endowment for the
Humanities, where she worked
closely with faculty and
administration at many colleges

New Faculty
and Administration
and universities, will be a distinct
asset to the central
administration at Johns
Hopkins."
Cole studied at Wheaton
College in Illinois and the
University of Michigan, Ann
Arbor, where she received the
bachelor's degree in English and
French in 1963 and a master's
degree in comparative literature
the following year. She also has
studied at the Johns Hopkins
School of Advanced
International Studies and holds a
Ph.D. degree in American studies
from George Washington
University.
Dr. Cole joined the National
Endowment for the Humanities
in 1970 as a program specialist in
the Division of Education
Programs. She was appointed
assistant director of the division
in 1975, assuming responsibility
for the administration of four
institutional grants programs
sponsored by NEH. Earlier in her
career she taught English and
French at several colleges and
held positions in the field of
urban planning and development.
Joining Dr. Cole as a new
appointee is Donald C. Klein,
who has been named adjunct
professor (part-time) of applieC
behavioral sciences and
psychology in the Evening
College's Division of Arts and
Sciences. Dean of the Johns
Hopkins Evening College, Roman
J. Verhaalen announced the
appointment.
Klein
Dr. Klein is the third
individual appointed to this
special instructional rank
reserved for a small core of
distinguished part-time faculty in
the Evening College.
A graduate of Roosevelt
University in Chicago, Dr. Klein
received his Ph.D. in clinical
psychology from the University
of California at Berkeley. He also
has studied epidemiology and

Amilb

mental health consultation at the
Harvard School of Public Health.
From 1967 to 1975, Dr. Klein
was program manager for the
National Training Laboratory
Institute for Applied Behavioral
Science, prior to that he served as
director of the Human Relations
Center and associate professor of
psychology and director of the
doctoral program in community
psychology at Boston University.

A certified psychologist in the
State of Maryland, he is the
author of numerous books,

an adjunct faculty member of the
Union Graduate School in

As adjunct professor in the

Hopkins Fellows program, a

skills within planned

change efforts.
Young Scholars
In addition to the
administration appointments,
nine young scholars have been
appointed assistant professors at
Hopkins.
Solid State
David R. Yarkony has been
appointed in the Department of
Chemistry. Dr. Yarkony earned
his Ph. D. degree in chemistry
from the University of California
at Berkeley in 1975. His research
interests include electronic
structure theory, scattering
theory and solid state theory.
Olson
In the Department of Earth
and Planetary Sciences, Peter Lee
Olson has been appointed an
assistant professor. Dr. Olson's
areas of specialization are
geophysical fluid dynamics and
the seneration of the earth's

Ph.D. degree from the University

Duo

Writin'

and acting director of the

appointment at Johns Hopkins,
received his master's degree in

University of Iowa. His book,

and he has contributed to "The

edited by Daniel Halpern. Mr.
White, who received a B.A. in
Chinese literature and language
from the University of Michigan,
is a novelist and playwright. In
1973, Random House published
his novel, "Forgetting Elena,"

German

appointed in the Department of

Wilson
W. Stephen Wilson has bee
appointed an associate professor
in the Department of
Mathematics. After receiving his
Ph.D. from the Massachusetts

Dr. Wilson joined the faculty at
Princeton University. His field of
interest is algebraic topology.

find that the book you've been
using has disappeared. Now, with
an effective security system and a
little student cooperation, these
books can remain in the library,

Baltimore Audiences Have Choice
BY MIKE GIULIANO
The Office of the Chaplain's Reel World, now in its
fifth year, is the biggest film series in Baltimore,
presentirig more than sixty films (roughly half
Hollywood, half foreign) on Wednesday and Sunday
evenings at 7:30 p.m. All screenings are on the
Homewood campus and most are in Shriver Hall. Because
the Reel World is well-established and reasonably wellpublicized it attracts an audience from most sections of
the city (and even a few determined film buffs from
Columbia.)
According to a Reel World organizer, more residents of
the Charles Village - Mount Vernon area than Hopkins'
students hold Reel World subscriptions. Particularly
unfortunate, if not surprising, is the Tact that "very few
undergraduates take part." As a part of this year's
freshman orientation program and, perhaps, also in an
effort to encourage undergraduate participation in the
series, freshmen were admitted free to this year's opening
film, Charles Chaplin's Modern Times. Around one
hundred fifty freshmen took advantage of this free
admission, and the total attendance was an encouraging
four hundred thirty. (A Reel World presentation usually
draws around one hundred people.)
Series admissions are by subscription only. There are
various plans: sixty admissions for thirty five dollars,
thirty for twenty two dollars, twelve for ten dollars, six
for six dollars, and four for five dollars. The next Reel
World presentation is Jan Kadar's Shop On Main Street, a
Czech film that has enjoyed international acclaim since its
showing at the Czechoslovak Film Week in London in
1965; it will be shown this Sunday, September 11.
Another Czech film, Ivan Passer's Intimate Lighting
(1967), will follow on September 14. For further
information call the Office of the Chaplain at 338-8187.
Another film series, the one at the Hopkins Graduate
Club (basement of McCoy Hall), will run on Thursday
evenings at eight p.m. Unlike previous films at the Grad
Club, there will be a one dollar admission charge for this
series, which opens on September 15 with Sidney Lumet's
Long Day's Journey Into Night.
Center Stage (700 N. Calvert St.), encouraged by the
success of its summer film program, is beginning its fall
series on September ninth and tenth with two Esther
Williams films: The Gang's All Here at 7:30 p.m. and
Areplune's Daughter at 9:30. Upcoming are
John Waters' latest film, Desperate Living, on September
16 and 17;W oody Allen's Bananas, Take The Money and
Run and What's Up Tiger Lily? on September 23 and 24;
a Black musical film festival on September 28,29,30 and
October 1; Meet Me In St. Louis and A Star Is Born
(1945) on October 7 and 8; Putney Swope and The
Producers on October 14 and 15. The price of admission

is $2 for adults ($3.50 for a double feature) and one
dollar for children. Because show times often vary from
weekend to the next it's advisable to call the Center Stage
box office at 332-0033.
The Baltimore Film Forum also screens its films at
Center Stage. Their programs begin at eight p.m. on
Mondays. The tentative schedule is as follows: Greta
Garbo in Painted Veil on September 19; Rene Clair's The
Last- Millionaire on October 17; Claude Chabrol's Les
Biches on November 21; Werner Herzog's Even Dwarfs
Started Small and Fata Morgana on December 19;
Rouben Mamoulian's Applause on January 23; Alain
Resnais' La Guerre Est Finie on February 27; Agnes
Varda's Les Creatures on March 13; and Yasujiro Ozu's
An Autumn Afternoon on May 15. Short films, program
notes, `post-film discussions and refreshments are
included. A single membership to the eight films costs
twenty dollars; a double membership, which admits the
bearer and one guest, costs thirty five dollars; a sustaining
membership, which admits the bearer and two guests,
costs fifty dollars; and a student/senior citizen
membership costs fifteen dollars. For additional
information write the Film Forum, P.O. Box 903,
Baltimorz, 21203, or call its president, Stuart Rome, at
467-2092.
Forum members, in addition to ticket discounts at the
Baltimore Film Festival held each spring, are entitled to a
considerable subscription discount to the Modern
European Directors: (Hopkins) Professors' Choice series
at the Baltimore Museum of Art auditorium. A series
subscription costs five dollars for Forum and Museum of
Art members, twenty dollars for non-members.
Subscribers can bring guests at three single admission to
each film. Screenings are on Thursdays at eight p.m.
Richard Macksey, chairman of the Humanities Center,
is series moderator. The films to be shown and lecturers
to be heard are: Michelangelo Antonioni's Blow Up on
September 29, lecture by William Arrowsmith of the
Humanities Center; Antonioni's The Passenger on October
6, lecture by Arrowsmith; Wim Winders' Kings of the
Road on October 13, lecture by Ralph Harper of the
Evening College; Wenders' Scarlet Letter on October 20,
lecture by Harper; Jean Renoir's La Bete Humaine on
October 27, lecture by Leo Braudy of the English
department; Eric Rohmer's Chloe In The AFternoon on
November 3, lecture by Braudy; Bernardo Bertolucci's
The Spider's Stratagem on November 10, lecture by
Phoebe Stanton of the History of Art department; Alain
Resnais' Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime on November 17, lecture
by Stanton; Laurence Olivier's Richard III on December
1, lecture by Mark Miller, formerly of the Humanities
Center, currently a professor of English at the University
of Pennsylvania; and Max Ophuls' The Earrings of
Madame De ... on December 8,lecture by Miller.

Brazil

Brazil
It was somewhere in 1971, and the place (naturally)
was Miles Davis' band. It was the new band, big and
electric, with several odd instruments, a number of young
whites, and a formidable stack of amplifiers. In the midst
of it all, among such stars as Gary Bartz, Keith Jarrett,
and John McLaughlin, was an odd, bearded Brasillian,
with a rather large variety of noisemakers. He would
shake them, scrape them, and do what seemed to be just
any old thing, always adding an interesting texture, but
no discernable pulse.
Sometime later, a record appeared, put together by
some of Miles old musicians. Joe Zawinul and Wayne
Shorter had formed an electric, impressionist quintet
called Weather Report, and there in the rhythm section
was this same Brasillian. His name was Airto Moriea, and
this time around, he added as much color as rhythm ,
nicely rounding Al Mouzon's drumming.
Still later, Chick Corea came out with an album called
Return To Forever. Produced by Manfred Eicher for his
ECM lable, the album was quite a change from Corea's
previous group, an exploratory hard bop ensemble
featuring Anthony Braxton. Along with his newly-found
left hand, Stanley Clarke, there was Airto, this time with
his wife, Flora Purim.
Airto and Flora were the beginning of an invasion of
wave" Brasillian jazz, an invasion that has yet to
reach its peak. Unlike the previous Brasillian intrusions
(Samba, Bossa Nova, etc), this new wave maintains much
of its native flavor, while keeping its strictly jazz sense. It
uses a complex, contagious beat, laced under a delicate
sense of harmony and an almost Rhapsodic sense of
melody.
At the vanguard right now, is Milton Nascimento.
Milton is this generation's Jobim, but unlike Jobim, he
can sing his own songs with nonpareil grace and finesse.
He has only one album in print over here, but he has
appeared on Wayne Shorter's Native Dancer, Flora
Purim's 500 Miles High, and Airto's Promises ofthe Sun.

They've played for crowds of
upwards of fifteen thousand
people to standing ovations.
They've worked with acts like
Loggins and Messina, Neil
Sedaka, The Band, Judy Collins,
Bette Midler and David Bromberg
-- delighting all these audiences.
In small halls and large arenas all
across the country Aztec
Two-Step have generated a
warmth and intensity that few
performers can match. Now Rex
Fowler and Neal Shulman Aztec Two-Step, have brought
their magic to Hopkins. With

their concert tonight at nine
o'clock, they should give
Hopkins the same electric
performance they have become
known for nationwide.
For the past few years, Rex
Fowler and Neal Shulman, Aztec
Two-Step, have been weaving a
unique patchwork of folk, rock
and country. Wherever they
perform, their loyal, fanatical
and always vocal fans come out
to support them. They have
created something of a legend
about themselves. There was that
unforgettable weekend gig at The

Unicorn in Ithaca, New York
where Neal and Rex set the house
attendance record. And there was
the time they attracted fourteen
hundred devotees to the
University of Rhode Island where
people climbed through windows
twelve feet off the ground and
literally sat on the rafters to hear
"Baking," "Dean Moriarty" and
"Humpty Dumpty."
Aztec Two-Step has been in
existence since the summer of
1971. At the time, Rex, a native
of Maine, and Neal, a
full-blooded New Yorker, were

Airto, OPA, and friends.

from left to right: George Duke, Ndugu, Alphonse

1

working independently in the
Boston area. They met at an
open hoot at the Stone Phoenix
Coffeehouse while both were
trying to subsist as solo folk
singers. They immediately dug
each other's material felt that
there was more strength in a duo.
On that summer night, Aztec
Two-Step was born.
Rex and Neal then rehearsed
for several weeks and played the
Unicorn, a fabled Boston
coffeehouse which was a major
stepping stone. for Dylan, Baez,
Jesse Cohn Young, Tom Rush

and Eric: Andersen, to name but
a few. The musical combination
of Neal's urban perceptions and
Rex's mild, agrarian background
clicked instantly. The next day,
after an overwhelming
performance, they set out for the
Big Apple and a recording
contract.
Now "Two's Company"
further realizes their vision. With
the help of producer Mark
Abramson, whose exquisite work
with Judy Collins is well known,
Rex and Neal have found the
delicate balance they've been
looking for. With eleven songs, all
written or co-written by Rex,
with the exception of
"Penthouse" by Jake Jacobs,
"Two's Company" is full of the
depth and lyricism, the strong
melodies and subtle harmonies
that have endeared them to their
fans. Theirs is what Rex describes
as "really personal music." It's
close to the heart.
Of course, no record can equal
the thrill of Aztec Two Step in
concert, and since Rex and Neal
rarely get a chance -to play
Baltimore, come watch them rip
this joint.

As far as I can recall, the initial shiver of imagination
was somehow prompted by a newspaper story about an
ape in the Jardin des Plan tes who, after months of
coaxing by a scientist, produced the first drawing ever
charcoaled by an animal: this sketch showed the bars of
the poor creature's cage -- Vladimir Nabokov on Lolita
If, as many have said, Baltimore is a jungle, then
certainly Johns Hopkins is a zoo. So it comes as no
surprise that when presented with a blank piece of paper
by my keeper, I naturally began to
describe: my
cage. Of course I've been allowed to roam at will through
the more natural parts of the preserve for the past two
years, all the while cleverly doging the tourists' cars, but
walls do not a prison make, and all we non-native Hopkins
students share a certain common sense of territoriality in
respect to Baltimore. We are cramped by these subliminal
impulses completely beyond our control, the secret force
fields that oscillate with every wind change. But this does
not mean we should be content to be passive resistors. We
can, we have to expand our limits; we must become
open-ended functions.
So, this. A doxology to Hopkins and Baltimore, an
anthem of non-sacramental sentiment. Why? Because I
am. Because I am a Hopkins students. Because I am
Hopkins.

•

The pale faces of freshmen groping for reassurance that
their lives are not mistakes look to the front of Shriver
Hall for the welcoming words of comfort from President
Muller and friends. President Muller, Provost Longaker,
and Dean Hall are all wearing identical shoes, black
leather loafers with gold chain buckles. Does this mean
anything;
Muller is introduced as "a man who has certainly
contributed to the greatness of the university," and why
should anyone quibble with such an innocuous cliche?
"Pardon the shirtsleeves," he syas, "and just try to hang
on." Ah, the statistics. There are 562 freshmen, 71% male
(applause from the audience), 29% female (less applause).

'

what the fuck's the matter?" The guy in the gray
Continental flips the bird out his sunroof and slowly pulls
out.

of their secondary school class, seventy three percent in
the upper tenth. Sixty four percent are from public
schools, thirty six percent from "independent" schools.

BY ANDREW COHEN
A new
stunting, aggressive defense is offering Coach Dennis Cox
and his Blue Jay football players hopes of finishing the
season in better fashion than their three previous
campaigns.
So disappointed was Coach Cox in his team's previous
performances that he decided to give both his offense and
defense minor face lifts. Instead of handling the scoring
team as he has in years past, Cox will turn those duties
over to assistant coach Willie Scroggs. The headcoach will
run the defense.
"We plan to employ a wide open offense similar to that
employed by the University of Houston," explained Cox.
"This year our fans will see a lot of option plays; passing,
pitching out to the running backs, and extensive running
by the quarterback."
This year's starting quarterback will be Tom Bender, a
junior from Rosedale, Maryland. It will be Bender's third
season as the Blue Jay signal caller and Cox is expecting
big things from this veteran. Just behind Bender stand
senior Bob DeSimone of Plainview, New York and
sophomore Joel Hansen from Chantilly, Virginia.
The tailback positions are aptly filled. by Ken Bess, a
senior from Laurel, and a strong frosh candidate, Bernie
Cook of Cockesville. Baltimore boy John Railey, Kevin
Keefer of Westminster, and Tom Meurer, also from
Baltimore, will take the fullback spots. Wide receivers
Dave Campbell of Pikesville and Joe Devlin of Annapolis
combined with tight-end Steve Wey of Baltimore should
strength-en the Jay passing attack.
The offensive line is chock full of experience with its
list of returning lettermen: Bob Divers, Rick Law, Rick
Broadhurst, and Chuck Kennedy. A battle does exist for
the remaining spot between freshmen Jim Hood of

Baltimore and Ron Chesek of Dundalk, Maryland.
Looking at Defense, the guard positions seem to have
been secured by lettermen Ned Sacha of Baltimore and
Chuck Hauck of Owings Mills, Maryland. Letterman Dave
Budzik will handle the left tackle duties while frosh Cook
and Hood battle it out for the right tackle post. Doober
Aburn of Towson and Him Schoettler of Chevy Chase will
be at the defensive end spots.
an interesting
In the linebacker category, Cox sees
battle developing over the two starting positions. Junior
letterman Sonny Mills, Divers, Meurer, and Keefer should
all be playing in those spots this season. John Scully of
Elicott City, Maryland will take the defensive halfback
post.
This season Cox has also expanded his kicking game,
employing Steve Love, a junior from Thurmount,

Marybrid, to boot field goals and kickoffs. The punting
team will consist of Tom Meurer and John Railey. Cox is
hoping that Love's foot will add an extra scoring
dimension that he could not count on in previous year.
The Blue Jays will scrimmage this weekend at Lebanon
Valley College before opening their season the following
week at Susquehanna University. The first home game
will take place on Homewood Field on September 24
when the Jays meet Muhlenberg.
Cox looks at his Middle Atlantic Conference Southern
Division schedule as a tough one. "Certainly, the team to
beat is Franklin and Marshall," cited the head coach.
"Widener should also offer some tough competition." No
matter how tough the schedule is this year Cox fully
expects the team to better last year's mark of 3-5-1.

B ryan
Flo Bryan, one of the leading young tennis prospects in
the Baltimore area at this time, has been appointed coach
of the Women's Tennis team at Johns Hopkins. Robert
Scott, Director of Athletics, beamed with pride as he
announced,"She is not only an excellent tennis instructor
but she is also such a delightful person. I just know,"
Scott continued, "our women will respond to her with
enthusiasm and pride."
Coach Bryan does indeed offer impressive credentials.
She has won five tennis tournaments in recent months
and was featured in a Sunday Sun Magazine picture story
on August 28 of this year. Since turning pro at age 19,she
has played in tournaments all over the country, adopting
the Baltimore area as her home during the past year.
Miss Bryan began playing tennis at age eleven, at which
time she was ranked in Florida as a leading Junior, and by
age fifteen she had participated in the nationally
recognized tournament at the Orange Bowl in Miami. She
became nationally ranked at age sixteen and was named
Number One in Virginia. After turning pro, she devoted
her full time to playing and teaching tennis.
Her recent tournament victories include the Middle
Atlantic Tennis Championships, the Margaret Chapman
Memorial Championship, the Evening Sun Municipals and
the State Hardcourt Championships. She was Maryland
State Champion in 1976.
Miss Bryan also has done extensive teaching in tennis.
She has taught at Country Clubs or clinics in Roanoke,
San Francisco, Charlottesville, and Orlando Florida.
Last spring she became coach of men's tennis at St.
Paul's School where she handled the varsity team. Mitch
Tullai, St. Paul's Athletic Director, spoke very highly of
her work at St. Paul's and his strong recommendation
confirmed Scott's resolve to offer her the tennis position.
At Hopkins she will work with a team that had
developed rapidly in recent years under Joyce Hogan,
who resigned last spring to devote full time to teaching.
The Johns Hopkins record last year was 7-4.

Morse
Micul Ann Morse will serve as Coordinator of Women's
Athletics at Johns Hopkins, having been appoined earlier
this year by the Director of Athletics, Robert H. Scott.
She replaces Dr. Joyce Hogan who resigned in May.
Mrs. Morse has been involved in the Hopkins athletic
program since the beginning of women's intercollegiate
sports in 1974, at which time she became coach of
women's lacrosse and field hockey as a part-time staff
member. She played an instrumental role in helping Johns
Hopkins over the transition from an all male school to a
coed school. Although her first hockey team had only
fourteen players, that number has since doubled. Coach
Morse has been an active participant in Baltimore Area
women's sports since graduating from East Stroudsburg
State College as a physical education major in 1967. After
an outstanding college career in both sports, she played
for both the Baltimore Women's Lacrosse Association and
the Baltimore Field Hockey Association, eventually
coaching the Baltimore lacrosse group. Mrs. Morse was
selected to the first team of the Southern District from
1969 to 1971 and was a player on the United States
Women's Lacrosse Assocation Touring Team that played
in England and Ireland. She also had been selected on the
first team of the Baltimore Field Hockey Assocation and
on the first team of the Southeast Field Hockey
Assocation.

New Life for Symposium comes from tube
CONIINUED FROM PAut I
chairpeople, Simms, Carole Jaffe, and Jill Leukhardt, feel that they will
be able to revitalize the event, so that it might return to its high
standards.
Their topic, which was selected by a student election last spring,
received an unusually high percentage of the vote. Simms felt that this
was an indication that his topic was something special. "We were only
the second symposium in eleven years to be selected by more than fifty
percent of the student body."
"Television and Society," said Simms, will cover nearly all aspects of
television -- the way it works in society, and the way the audience has
determined what will be on television. The average viewer will see that
he does have an impact."
"T.V. is changing society, but also society is changing itself," Simms
continued. "Television is a mirror of society. It's a mirror that doesn't
reflect every detail — it's a mirror that collects and condenses the
aspects of society that people seem to want to see."
The concept of this year's program, according to Simms,is "a critical
look at television," and its objective is "that those in attendance should
realize the effect of T.V. on them. They should be aware that the
program they're seeing is only bordering on reality."
Each speaker will have a valid point to make about television, and its
issues. Previous symposia were criticized by Simms for placing too
much emphasis on "big-name" speakers capable of filling Shriver Hall
but who failed to contribute to the program topic.
"The speakers are attractive enough to draw large audiences," he
stated, "but the purpose is not entertainment at the expense of
education. Those in attendance will really benefit from each segment.
We consider ourselves lucky to get this list of speakers who are both
audience-drawers and most authoratative in their fields."
"The speakers are cumulative," he continued. "The audience will
amek the conclusion at the end." A special session will be held
November 3, following Jim Bouton's presentation, to sum up and
evulate the series.

New security at Hut
BY CHRIS STUTZ
This year, as students make
their first reluctant passage
through the glass portals of the
Hutzler Reading Room, they will
encounter something new: an
electronic book security system.
Students will walk through a
frame-like structure immediately
inside the entrance which detects
the presence of sensitized
"objects" hidden in the books.
Due to the increasing number of
lost books in recent years, the
System was installed to. protect
the remaining volumes. If this
System is successful, another may
be purchased for use in the
Eisenhower library.
According to studies
C onducted by Shirley Baker,
Hutzler Undergraduate Librarian,
the most frequently used books

at Hutzler are the study aids, that
is, reference books and texts that
.supplement students' assigned
texts. Formerly, these texts were
available on a circulating basis
(except, of course, for
non-circulating reference
materials) but, because of their
value to students, they often
disappeared soon after their
purchase. Thus students who
came to Hutzler seeking a
specific and often crucial text,
such as Lehninger or the CRC
Handbook, could never depend
upon finding it on the shelves. It
is in the interest of serving the
entire student body, therefore,
that this security system has been
instituted.
The most used portion of the
six thousand books in the
collection (about two-thirds)
have been made non-circulating,

The Johns Hopkins University
School Of Medicine has indicated
that it will sacrifice as much as
$700,000 next year in federal
assistance by refusing to change
its admissions policies for foreign
transfer students.
The school will become
ineligible to receive certain
federal grants because of its
refusal to comply with Section
771B, Title VII, of Public Law
94-484. This provision, part of a
Health Manpower bill, calls for a
school seeeking renewed grants to
agree to accept a government-set
quota of U.S. citizens who have
begun their medical studies
abroad.
According to the provision,
the eligibility of these students
would be determined solely by
the Department of Health,
Education, and Welfare. The only
university criteria they would
have to meet would be entrance
requirements, rather than
academic requirements. As
explained by medical school
Assistant Dean for Academic
Affairs Dr. John Yardley, this
would mean that an applicant
would be responsible for having
taken organic chemistry, for
example, but not for having
received an "A" or "B" mark in
that course, or any specified
grade point average.
In an open letter sent to
members of Congress, President
Steven Muller held that the
so that they are always available
for those who need them. The
other two thousand books are
stored at another location and
can be obtained on request. Ms.
Baker has been in contact with
faculty and the MSE Reserve
Room staff in order to determine
which books should be kept in
Hutzler for general use and which
should be allowed to circulate.
She welcomes suggestions from

Hopkins and CIA: No big sneeze
On August 18, the Johns
Hopkins University was notified
that it was among the eighty
Institutions involved in the
C I A- fu nded MK-ULTRA
Program. The announcement,
which came two days after the
University of Maryland had
received a similar notice, has
been perhaps the only clear piece
of information in the unravelling
of this rather curious spy tale.
Between November, 1958 and
August, 1962, CIA monies were
used to finance a study of highly
'allergic substances." Just what
those substances wre, and who
Was involved in their production

is unclear, and because of the
sketchy nature of the facts of the
case, it is doubtful that they ever
will be. Still, according to the
University's general counsel,
Estelle A. Fishbein, there was no
indication that the research
involved human subjects.
Perhaps the principal reason
for the enigma is that the bulk of
the MK-ULTRA records now
extant are mostly financial
rec ords, and add only
fragmentary information on the
nature of each of the projects.
Oddly enough, until these
records had been found, most of
the information on MK ULTRA

was believed to have Peen
destroyed in 1973, according to a
statement by the agency's general
counsel, Anthony A. Lapham.
Most of the documents
examined by Mrs. Fishbein were
vouchers and expense forms,
averaging about four thousand
dollars a year. Fishbein noted
that there was an "inordinate"
amount of paperwork concerning
an $18.26 discrepancy.
As for the nature of the
research itself, less is clear. One
of the documents inspected
stated that the Hopkins work was
"To purify and characterized
-SEE MATERIALS, PAGE 15

provision "violates the rights of
the University under the First
and Fifth Amendments of the
Constitution of the United
States."
Muller further cited a Supreme
Court decision in which Justice
Felix Frankfurter declared that
one of the four essential
freedoms of a university is "the
right to determine for itself on
academic grounds ... who may be
admitted to study."
In addition to its philosophical
objections, the school also claims
that it cannot increase its
enrollment without lowering the
quality of instruction, and that
foreign medical students are
provided opportunities to enter
the school under its regular
admissions procedures.
President Muller's letter
continues, "The Johns Hopkins
University, after careful
deliberation, and on the basis of
full endorsement in particular by
medical faculty, takes the
position that preservation of
Constitutional rights and
academic integrity leaves no
alternative to non-acceptance."
The six year old program in
question involves capitation
grants, or grants based on the
number of students enrolled.
According to Yardley, the figure
is usually about one thousand
dollars per student, with amounts
up to fourteen hundred being
considered for I 972,Depending

on the Congressional
appropriation, then, the amount
at stake could range from four
hundred thousand to seven
hundred thousand dollars.
University officials hope that
Congress will repeal or amend the
Health Manpower act. Yardley
noted that the provision in
question was added at the last
moment by a Senate-House
conference committee, and that
it was overlooked in debate on
the measure. The University
hopes that bringing the matter to
the attention of Congress may
induce them to act upon it.
An amendment to the
provision has already been
introduced into Congress. This
measure would limit the number
of HEW selected transfer
students to five percent of the
class, or ten students, whichever
is greater. In Hopkins' case, ten
such students would have to be
accepted each year. Yardley
stated that such a figure is still
too high to be acceptable.
In the event that Hopkins loses
its capitation grant funds, Muller
emphasized that the budget at
the medical school will be
reduced. "The resulting financial
burden will not be placed on the
medical students of the
university," the letter states.
• Tuition will be increased at the
medical school next year,
however, due to other factors.

Symposium opens Oct. 6th
"Television and Society: the World in 21" (Diagonally)"
this year's topic for the Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium, will open its
lecture series with Canadian media critic Marshall McLuhan, on October
6 in Shriver Hall.
The Symposium,which is in its eleventh year, began in 1967 as a
tribute to then president Milton Eisenhower. Commenting on the
topical nature of the lectures, Symposium Co-chairman Steve Simms
commented, "In the spirit he helped to encourage, the symposium
explores issues of contemporary impact."
Among previous topics were such issues as "The Nature of
Creativity," "The United States and the Soviet Union: The Dilemma of
Power," and "Aspects of Human Sexuality." Generally, the series draws
wide attention in the media, and several lectures from the Nature of
Creativity were taped for broadcast by PBS. An integral part of
Baltimore's intellectual life, the Symposium's lectures often attract as
many community residents as students.
Unfortunately, not all of the topics succeed, and last years' series,"A
Question of Freedom," was less than successful. Plagued by poor
attendance and little-known speakers, it was felt by some that the

nEW1 LECCER
Legislative Morality
Throughout the history of our country, there have been
many discriminatory laws, laws which were not so much
used to marshall order as to stratify class boundaries.
Prohibition, for example, was violated as much by the
upper classes as by the lower, yet was primarily used as a
means of harassment for many lower-class immigrant
groups, especially Irish and Italian Catholics. Similarly, the
marijuana laws have been seen by some (e.g., Garry Wills) as
a means of persecuting the lower class urban dweller, while
the upper class suburbanites are rarely bothered.
Most recently, President Carter engaged in an action
which discriminates not only against class but against sex.
By restricting the use of Federal Health funding to disclude
abortions. Carter has sought to enforce a moral decision '
against a legalistic problem, and in ding so, has attempted'
to decide the morality of a question for others.
In a nutshell, our position is this: If Medical aid is the
right of every individual (and, indeed, this seems to be the
Government's position as well; viz. Medicare, HEW, etc.),
then anymedical operation which is legal in the United
States should be available to all citizens. So long as the
government condones abortion with legality, it is clarly
discriminatory to deny it to those unable to afford it.
The issue here is not whether abortion is moral. The
Right to Life movement should direct their energies to the
repeal of the abortion laws, not the repeal of Federal
funding. President Carter should realize that morality
cannot be legislated, either through direct or indirect
means.

This age of science, like all ages, is a period of
faith in the non-observable, and an age considerably
less practical in all of the important respects than
the age of the religious world view. In that age,
inquisitions and religious wars were, in the first
place, political perversions of an existential
standpoint created by a man who frustrated the
hopes of his contemporaries by insisting that His.
kingdom was not of this world; and, in any event,
modernity can make no claims to comparative
innocence. Our age of rationalism, of "scientific"
ideology, is curiously simultaneous with terrorism,
totalitarianism, and destructive revolution on an
unprecedented scale. Science has so completely
failed to substantiate anyone's humanistic optimism
that its apotheosis is now virtually unheard of. This
development has to do not only with the fact that
science is the matrix of destructive capacity as well
as constructive capacity, but with the fact that
"scientific" analysis brooks no distinctively religious
problems as such in human subjectivity. Rather, it
attempts to analyze these "prima facie" religious
problems into something else, reducing them, in
not
effect, to something that they are
radical empiricism;
experienced as. This is not
it is, rather the ideologizing of man,and it does not
work.
It is the death of man. The modern secular
psychological project, beginning most dramatically
with psychoanalysis in the late nineteenth century,
rooted itself in the rejection of the inexplicable face
of experience in a search for its mechanistic guts.
This was a rejection of the radically experiential
method of defining man for ideological ways of
doing so. The point is that man experiences
freedom, guilt, responsibility, transcendence, and,
traditionally in the West, these were viewed not as
illusions, but rather as the foundational realities of
Man. With the advent of modern scientific analysis
we adopted the assumption that we are simply
fooled into believing these things about ourselves;
the methodological assumption of a hopefully
comprehensive science was that everything had a
cause. Thus we ended up explaining ourselves in
terms of an ideological determinism which we could
not observe and rejecting the freedom, guilt,
responsibility, and transcendence which we could
observe.
Now I certainly think that there is something
definitely specious about this, especially insofar as
we are the ones who come up with the ideology. It
is not that I reject the causal foundations of natural
science, but rather that I reject this foundation as a
comprehensive view of things. It seems odd to apply
it to a consciousness which objectifies the causal
nexus and seems always in a position to break it
once it is known. Sartre, of course, would agree.
Man, from a radically experiential standpoint, is
freedom.
But it is not this rather abstruse philosophical
insight which has broken down psychoanalysis in
less than one hundred years; rather, I am inclined to
believe it is the latter's comparative therapeutic
failure. Today the psychiatrist often deals in
"reality therapy," or "logo-therapy," in which the
face of subjective experience is accepted and the
patient is expected to own up to freedom,
responsibility, and the necessity of decisions leading
to meaning:We live in an era in which a Carl Becker
understands all human behavior as an existential
strategy for escaping death, death as subjective
nothingness, meaninglessness, valuelessness, and
lovelessness. All of which goes to say that we are
turning back to ourselves instead of paying homage
to "scientific" ideology.
But this revolution 114s.only just begun and the
average modern man has not even begun to digest its

Two days ago, as a part of Full Employment Week, the
Interdenominational Minesterial Alliance and the
AFL-CIO staged rallies at City Hall and Center Plaza in an
attempt to call public attention to the current high rate of
unemployment, particularly among blacks. More than
Twenty Baltimore ministers, among them Chaplain
Chester Wickwire, presented a staement which accused
our national leaders of "committing themselves to the
proposition of maintaining high rates of unemployment to
offset the rising price levels attendant to inflation." Such
a policy, of course, shows a crass disregard for the lives of
those unemployed. Particularly hard hit is the Black
community, where the unemployment rate is around 14%.
The percentage of unemployed black adolescents averages
35% and is as high as 70% . In fact, Baltimore ranks
second to Detroit in its rate of unemployment among
black teenagers. The IMA is asking that ;ndividuals write
letters to President Carter and to Representative Parren
Mitchell expressing their concern. Among other things,
they hope that the office of Revenue Sharing will
investigate the use of federal funds in our city and state to
evaluate their availability and use for the needy.
Dr. Wickwire stressed that "we shouldn't be dealing with
economic problems in terms of inflation, but dealing with
them in terms of people." He went on to criticize the lack
of social concern at Hopkins. "How far removed we are
on campus from what's going on down in the city. We're
so isolated from what's going on on the other side of
North Avenue." This coming Sunday, ministers
throughout the city will ask their congregations to write
the President. On campus, Dr. Wickwire hopes that within
the next few days individuals will write letters to Carter
and then drop them off at the office of the Chaplain,
where, sometime early next week, the hopefully large
.

tho
stack of mail will be given to the Postal Service. We
urgeChaPlain will find that the sort of public program
A students and faculty members to add to the stack.
that he seems to presently promote is hopelessly
Y kJ

non-religious and therefore uninteresting to religious
people as such. The aesthetic surface of a chaplain's
program which is constituted out of religion
courses, ostensibly stuffy seminars about
"individual and societal growth" or "issues in health
care delivery," and volunteer work which could as
well be provided by an Office of Mundane
recherche "relevance." But it is also the reduction
of religion to good anthropology, good ethics, good
politics, and good humanism; and as good as it all is,
it is merely paltry when placed beside Christ's
radical denial of subjective death - this being the
most sublime religious issue in life.
There is no morally authentic humanism in a man
(there is no strength for it) until he has solved the
irreducibly and distinctively religious problem of
life as a personal abyss in which there is the failure
to instantiate value, radical contingency, a dearth of
hope and love, and an abiding despair that he can
only run from. The Chaplain's public program
seems, in the face of this, religiously irrelevant another manifestation of the impoverished modern
emphasis: the relation of ideology to man and man
to man rather than, firstly, the relation of man to
his own subjectivity and consequently to God. It
excludes the religiously fundamental search for a
healthy subjective authenticity. Thus the Chaplain
seems to offer us one more moment in the silence of
God, unless a course on "individual growth" is more
than ideological.
Hegel pointed out that the dialectical product of
God's death is not the promotion of man, but,
rather, the deification of Death itself. But the
scientific age has only "killed" God as a necessary
aspect of limited scientific explanations as such and
cannot, even in principle, "kill" him as a moral
n.ecesity,. not an ultimate explanation. Still, even if
the "death of God" cannot be produced
scientifically and is actually identical with ignorance
of God,the practical effect is not that man becomes
God but, once again, that Death becomes God. The
universe not only remains ultimately inexplicable to
man, but his history becomes a reign of terror. One
hundred years ago Zarathustra came out of the hills
to announce the death of God (albeit, too early);
Orwell and Huxley, in their more recent
pronouncement were much more modest: they
merely descried the death of Man (albeit, too late).
The seemingly manufactured "relevance" of
contemporary "religion" is no resurrection,for it
does not return us to the face of human subjectivity
(nor consequently to the face of God.)
Still, this exact moment of the age remains
uncertain, not clearly a decision to remain with
Death, palling of its own tawdriness. It has squeezed
the magnitude out of everything, including sex,
marriage, and childbearing. In doing so it waters an
already rooted existential rebellion in human nature
which cannot long bear the total absence of the
goodness accruing frOm the fulfillment of moral
duty. The contemporary man's and woman's
totalitarian and loveless behavior toward their own
unborn children is perhaps the most repulsive and
extreme selfishness teleologically implied by the
death of all moral authority - the death of God. The
ugliness, the hollowness, the simple moral
bankruptcy of the West is now unendurable. What
we shall probably have to protect ourselves against
in the next tens to twenty years is the fascist
potential in the inevitable human reaction to it. We
will have to insure that the form this reaction takes
is not politically or religiously authoritarian, but a
matter of religious grace. In this sense, Christ is the
model for authority. Nevertheless, this is not a
model of innocuous piety, for Christ the tiger (as
Eliot put it) subjectively radicalizes men and women
in the face of Death.
--Thomas A. Dahlberz

Film Series

Baltimore Audiences Have Choice
BY MIKE GIULIANO
The Office of the Chaplain's Reel World, now in its
fifth year, is the biggest film series in Baltimore,
presentirig more than sixty films (roughly half
Hollywood, half foreign) on Wednesday and Sunday
evenings at 7:30 p.m. All screenings are on the
Homewood campus and most are in Shriver Hall. Because
the Reel World is well-established and reasonably wellpublicized it attracts an audience from most sections of
the city (and even a few determined film buffs from
Columbia.)
According to a Reel World organizer, more residents of
the Charles Village - Mount Vernon area than Hopkins'
students hold Reel World subscriptions. Particularly
unfortunate, if not surprising, is the Tact that "very few
undergraduates take part." As a part of this year's
freshman orientation program and, perhaps, also in an
effort to encourage undergraduate participation in the
series, freshmen were admitted free to this year's opening
film, Charles Chaplin's Modern Times. Around one
hundred fifty freshmen took advantage of this free
admission, and the total attendance was an encouraging
four hundred thirty. (A Reel World presentation usually
draws around one hundred people.)
Series admissions are by subscription only. There are
various plans: sixty admissions for thirty five dollars,
thirty for twenty two dollars, twelve for ten dollars, six
for six dollars, and four for five dollars. The next Reel
World presentation is Jan Kadar's Shop On Main Street, a
Czech film that has enjoyed international acclaim since its
showing at the Czechoslovak Film Week in London in
1965; it will be shown this Sunday, September 11.
Another Czech film, Ivan Passer's Intimate Lighting
(1967), will follow on September 14. For further
information call the Office of the Chaplain at 338-8187.
Another film series, the one at the Hopkins Graduate
Club (basement of McCoy Hall), will run on Thursday
evenings at eight p.m. Unlike previous films at the Grad
Club, there will be a one dollar admission charge for this
series, which opens on September 15 with Sidney Lumet's
Long Day's Journey Into Night.
Center Stage (700 N. Calvert St.), encouraged by the
success of its summer film program, is beginning its fall
series on September ninth and tenth with two Esther
Williams films: The Gang's All Here at 7:30 p.m. and
Areplune's Daughter at 9:30. Upcoming are
John Waters' latest film, Desperate Living, on September
16 and 17;W oody Allen's Bananas, Take The Money and
Run and What's Up Tiger Lily? on September 23 and 24;
a Black musical film festival on September 28,29,30 and
October 1; Meet Me In St. Louis and A Star Is Born
(1945) on October 7 and 8; Putney Swope and The
Producers on October 14 and 15. The price of admission

is $2 for adults ($3.50 for a double feature) and one
dollar for children. Because show times often vary from
weekend to the next it's advisable to call the Center Stage
box office at 332-0033.
The Baltimore Film Forum also screens its films at
Center Stage. Their programs begin at eight p.m. on
Mondays. The tentative schedule is as follows: Greta
Garbo in Painted Veil on September 19; Rene Clair's The
Last- Millionaire on October 17; Claude Chabrol's Les
Biches on November 21; Werner Herzog's Even Dwarfs
Started Small and Fata Morgana on December 19;
Rouben Mamoulian's Applause on January 23; Alain
Resnais' La Guerre Est Finie on February 27; Agnes
Varda's Les Creatures on March 13; and Yasujiro Ozu's
An Autumn Afternoon on May 15. Short films, program
notes, `post-film discussions and refreshments are
included. A single membership to the eight films costs
twenty dollars; a double membership, which admits the
bearer and one guest, costs thirty five dollars; a sustaining
membership, which admits the bearer and two guests,
costs fifty dollars; and a student/senior citizen
membership costs fifteen dollars. For additional
information write the Film Forum, P.O. Box 903,
Baltimorz, 21203, or call its president, Stuart Rome, at
467-2092.
Forum members, in addition to ticket discounts at the
Baltimore Film Festival held each spring, are entitled to a
considerable subscription discount to the Modern
European Directors: (Hopkins) Professors' Choice series
at the Baltimore Museum of Art auditorium. A series
subscription costs five dollars for Forum and Museum of
Art members, twenty dollars for non-members.
Subscribers can bring guests at three single admission to
each film. Screenings are on Thursdays at eight p.m.
Richard Macksey, chairman of the Humanities Center,
is series moderator. The films to be shown and lecturers
to be heard are: Michelangelo Antonioni's Blow Up on
September 29, lecture by William Arrowsmith of the
Humanities Center; Antonioni's The Passenger on October
6, lecture by Arrowsmith; Wim Winders' Kings of the
Road on October 13, lecture by Ralph Harper of the
Evening College; Wenders' Scarlet Letter on October 20,
lecture by Harper; Jean Renoir's La Bete Humaine on
October 27, lecture by Leo Braudy of the English
department; Eric Rohmer's Chloe In The AFternoon on
November 3, lecture by Braudy; Bernardo Bertolucci's
The Spider's Stratagem on November 10, lecture by
Phoebe Stanton of the History of Art department; Alain
Resnais' Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime on November 17, lecture
by Stanton; Laurence Olivier's Richard III on December
1, lecture by Mark Miller, formerly of the Humanities
Center, currently a professor of English at the University
of Pennsylvania; and Max Ophuls' The Earrings of
Madame De ... on December 8,lecture by Miller.

Brazil

Brazil
It was somewhere in 1971, and the place (naturally)
was Miles Davis' band. It was the new band, big and
electric, with several odd instruments, a number of young
whites, and a formidable stack of amplifiers. In the midst
of it all, among such stars as Gary Bartz, Keith Jarrett,
and John McLaughlin, was an odd, bearded Brasillian,
with a rather large variety of noisemakers. He would
shake them, scrape them, and do what seemed to be just
any old thing, always adding an interesting texture, but
no discernable pulse.
Sometime later, a record appeared, put together by
some of Miles old musicians. Joe Zawinul and Wayne
Shorter had formed an electric, impressionist quintet
called Weather Report, and there in the rhythm section
was this same Brasillian. His name was Airto Moriea, and
this time around, he added as much color as rhythm ,
nicely rounding Al Mouzon's drumming.
Still later, Chick Corea came out with an album called
Return To Forever. Produced by Manfred Eicher for his
ECM lable, the album was quite a change from Corea's
previous group, an exploratory hard bop ensemble
featuring Anthony Braxton. Along with his newly-found
left hand, Stanley Clarke, there was Airto, this time with
his wife, Flora Purim.
Airto and Flora were the beginning of an invasion of
wave" Brasillian jazz, an invasion that has yet to
reach its peak. Unlike the previous Brasillian intrusions
(Samba, Bossa Nova, etc), this new wave maintains much
of its native flavor, while keeping its strictly jazz sense. It
uses a complex, contagious beat, laced under a delicate
sense of harmony and an almost Rhapsodic sense of
melody.
At the vanguard right now, is Milton Nascimento.
Milton is this generation's Jobim, but unlike Jobim, he
can sing his own songs with nonpareil grace and finesse.
He has only one album in print over here, but he has
appeared on Wayne Shorter's Native Dancer, Flora
Purim's 500 Miles High, and Airto's Promises ofthe Sun.

else will do. Milton, like cocaine, is an acquired taste, but
one that can easily become insatiable.

Pascoal.Hermeto, unlike Milton, is more of a performer

They've played for crowds of

people to standing ovations.
They've worked with acts like
Loggins and Messina, Neil
Sedaka, The Band, Judy Collins,
Bette Midler and David Bromberg
-- delighting all these audiences.
In small halls and large arenas all
across the country Aztec
Two-Step have generated a
warmth and intensity that few
performers can match. Now Rex
Fowler and Neal Shulman Aztec Two-Step, have brought
their magic to Hopkins. With

their concert tonight at nine
o'clock, they should give
Hopkins the same electric
performance they have become
known for nationwide.
For the past few years, Rex
Fowler and Neal Shulman, Aztec
Two-Step, have been weaving a
unique patchwork of folk, rock
and country. Wherever they
perform, their loyal, fanatical
and always vocal fans come out
to support them. They have
created something of a legend
about themselves. There was that
unforgettable weekend gig at The

Unicorn in Ithaca, New York
where Neal and Rex set the house
attendance record. And there was
the time they attracted fourteen
hundred devotees to the
University of Rhode Island where
people climbed through windows
twelve feet off the ground and
literally sat on the rafters to hear
"Baking," "Dean Moriarty" and
"Humpty Dumpty."
Aztec Two-Step has been in
existence since the summer of
1971. At the time, Rex, a native
of Maine, and Neal, a
full-blooded New Yorker, were

from left to right: George Duke, Ndugu, Alphonse

1

working independently in the
Boston area. They met at an
open hoot at the Stone Phoenix
Coffeehouse while both were
trying to subsist as solo folk
singers. They immediately dug
each other's material felt that
there was more strength in a duo.
On that summer night, Aztec
Two-Step was born.
Rex and Neal then rehearsed
for several weeks and played the
Unicorn, a fabled Boston
coffeehouse which was a major
stepping stone. for Dylan, Baez,
Jesse Cohn Young, Tom Rush

and Eric: Andersen, to name but
a few. The musical combination
of Neal's urban perceptions and
Rex's mild, agrarian background
clicked instantly. The next day,
after an overwhelming
performance, they set out for the
Big Apple and a recording
contract.
Now "Two's Company"
further realizes their vision. With
the help of producer Mark
Abramson, whose exquisite work
with Judy Collins is well known,
Rex and Neal have found the
delicate balance they've been
looking for. With eleven songs, all
written or co-written by Rex,
with the exception of
"Penthouse" by Jake Jacobs,
"Two's Company" is full of the
depth and lyricism, the strong
melodies and subtle harmonies
that have endeared them to their
fans. Theirs is what Rex describes
as "really personal music." It's
close to the heart.
Of course, no record can equal
the thrill of Aztec Two Step in
concert, and since Rex and Neal
rarely get a chance -to play
Baltimore, come watch them rip
this joint.

As far as I can recall, the initial shiver of imagination
was somehow prompted by a newspaper story about an
ape in the Jardin des Plan tes who, after months of
coaxing by a scientist, produced the first drawing ever
charcoaled by an animal: this sketch showed the bars of
the poor creature's cage -- Vladimir Nabokov on Lolita
If, as many have said, Baltimore is a jungle, then
certainly Johns Hopkins is a zoo. So it comes as no
surprise that when presented with a blank piece of paper
by my keeper, I naturally began to
describe: my
cage. Of course I've been allowed to roam at will through
the more natural parts of the preserve for the past two
years, all the while cleverly doging the tourists' cars, but
walls do not a prison make, and all we non-native Hopkins
students share a certain common sense of territoriality in
respect to Baltimore. We are cramped by these subliminal
impulses completely beyond our control, the secret force
fields that oscillate with every wind change. But this does
not mean we should be content to be passive resistors. We
can, we have to expand our limits; we must become
open-ended functions.
So, this. A doxology to Hopkins and Baltimore, an
anthem of non-sacramental sentiment. Why? Because I
am. Because I am a Hopkins students. Because I am
Hopkins.
